title: Academic Kaffeeklatsch
event_description: Join your German Language Assistants, classmates, and faculty for food, coffee, and conversation. This is a great opportunity to practice your German in a casual and relaxing environment. German speakers of all levels are welcome!

title: CHEMINAR - Senior Thesis Talks
location: Science Center A011, Kirkpatrick Lecture Hall
event_description:
-Anna Baxter; Controlled Synthesis of Lamellar Polymer Brush Structures (Thesis Advisor: Prof Sandra Burkett)
-Kaila Bush; Carbon Cycling in Coastal Ecosystems, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) (Thesis Advisor: Prof Anna Martini)
-Isabelle Gomez; Controlling Nanotube Formation with a Photoswitchable Azobenzene “Bridge” (Thesis Advisor: Prof David Hansen)
-Britney Jiang; Optimizing Incorporation of Mn2+ Dopants in InP/ZnS Core/Shell Quantum Dots (Thesis Advisor: Prof Jacob Olshansky)

title: Physics & Astronomy Colloquium
event_description: Join the Physics & Astronomy department as we welcome Aurelia Ball from Skidmore College. Aurelia is presenting a talk titled "Molecular shape-shifters: Using computational biophysics to reveal cellular processes".

title: Extended Course Reserve Loans Through October Break
event_description: Starting Friday, October 11th, select reserve items can have due dates extended to 9 AM Wednesday, October 16th! You can check-out up to three (3) books from Frost, Music, and Science Reserves. The library must hold on to at least one copy of each reserve book in the library for 4 hour loans, but if we have more than one copy on reserve, those will be available for this extended loan time. Stop by to check-out your course texts today! (Note: This does not include equipment loans)

title: T4Tea
event_description: Join the WGC for the launch of our new series, T4Tea! We’ll be using tea bags as paint mediums to explore our relationships with our queer/trans bodies. All students are welcome, but we will be centering the experiences of students who identify as trans, nonbinary, and/or gender non-conforming, especially trans students of color. Boba from Lime Red will be provided!

title: CHI Salon - Repairing History
location: CHI Think Tank (Childcare provided in Lyceum 102)
event_description: What can we learn from a canoe older than the U.S., anchored to the bottom of a lake in Massachusetts today? What can we see by finding relationality between those whose lives and creations have been deemed "unarchivable," "unrecognizable," and “unrepairable”? Artist, visual storyteller, and scholar Kohar Avakian reflects on the relationship between the submerged Nipmuc mishoon and the creations featured in Boundless, an Indigenous art & literature exhibition at the Mead Museum.

title: Campus Business Project Notification: Science Center A Wing Paint Work
event_description: Please select the following link for more information regarding upcoming paint work in the A Wing of the Science Center, scheduled for October 14th-October 18th.

title: Project Notification-Webster Hall Window Inspections
event_description: Please select the following link for more information regarding upcoming window inspections at Webster Hall scheduled for Monday, October 14, 2024.

title: Project Notification- College Hall Driveway Paving
event_description: Please select the following link for more information regarding paving and regrading of the driveway behind College Hall that opens up onto Northampton Rd. This work is scheduled for 10/15/2024-10/18/2024 and will cause some limitations to driving and parking in that area, as well as noise, dust, and vibrations.

title: Prof. Jason Robinson Performs Ancestral Numbers at The Drake
event_description: Pioneer Valley Jazz Shares and The Drake will present a quintet version of Prof. Jason Robinson’s Janus Ensemble, featuring Robinson on saxophones and flute with trombonist Michael Dessen, pianist Joshua White, bassist Drew Gress, and drummer Ches Smith. The concert is part of a tour celebrating the release of a pair of new albums, Ancestral Numbers I and Ancestral Numbers II. Prof. Robinson’s latest musical project is motivated by a basic question: What does ancestry sound like?

title: I came here to weep: A conversation with the artist Yanira Castro
location: Friendly Reading Room, Frost Library (1st floor)
event_description:
Join us for a presentation and long table discussion connected to the public art project EXORCISM = LIBERATION by Puerto Rican-born, Brooklyn-based artist and choreographer Yanira Castro (AC ‘93).

Castro will be joined by Rachel De La Cruz and Paul Schroeder Rodriguez  and Luke Ortiz-Whittingham, who will share about their work with Casa Pueblo in Puerto Rico. The group will guide us in a conversation about relationships to climate disaster and how we might take care of one another.

title: La Mesa del Español
event_description:
The Spanish Table is a great place to practice your Spanish speaking skills while having lunch in Val (on the 2nd floor) from 12-2pm. As Latin American Language Assistants (Jorge from Mexico and Leo and Nadia from Argentina), we’ll be thrilled to share this enriching experience with you. Let’s engage in meaningful conversations and have lots of fun.

We are all looking forward to meeting you!

title: Media Influence and Consumer Literacy
event_description:
UMass-Amherst's International Programs Office, in coordination with colleagues from Amherst College, Hampshire College, Mount Holyoke College, and Smith College, is hosting a series of panel discussions every Monday evening in October over Zoom discussing issues related to the U.S. election cycle and how non-voting members of our shared community can engage with the process.

Monday, October 14, 6pm: Media Influence and Consumer Literacy

Register here: https://tinyurl.com/FCEP02

title: Queers will not be talking this Friday
event_description: Because of October break, there will be no Queer Talk this Friday, October 11th! We will back October 18th with our regularly scheduled programming. Enjoy your break!!

title: Baewatch: Beauty Standards at Amherst
event_description: Join the WGC, MRC, QRC, QTPOC, Peer Educators and CCMH for a discussion on beauty standards, relationships, with a particular focus on the effects that affirmative action has on the friendship/dating pool in a PWI. We will be focusing on BIPOC experiences on campus, so invite your friends! We will also have food from Formosa!! Contact wgc@amherst.edu for more questions. The Queer Resource Center is located on the second floor of Keefe Campus Center (room 213)

title: Make Your Voting Plan Over Break
event_description: Take some time over the break to finalize your voting plan! There’s still time to register in many states and request an absentee ballot in all states. Use TurboVote to help guide you—scroll to Vote by Mail to request your absentee ballot. Stay updated by checking out the @ACVotes Instagram and webpage for reminders and voting updates.

title: Pulse & Breath: A Weekly Moment to Honor What We Are Living Through
location: Religious & Spiritual Life, Keefe Campus Center #017
event_description:
Join us for a collective pause! Unplug and recharge in a nurturing space.

Stop by for 5 minutes of quiet or stay longer.

Enjoy silent contemplation and reflection in your own style: prayer, journaling, meditation, art and/or any other unplugged activity that helps you reconnect with yourself. (Journaling & Art supplies are available.)

Optional brief check-ins with Humanist and Interfaith Chaplain Wade

wboswell@amherst.edu for more info,

ALL ARE WELCOME

title: Help plan Amherst's first outdoor Pride festival
event_description: The Queer Resource Center is planning Amherst's first outdoor pride festival to celebrate LGBTQ+ students, staff, faculty, and alumni. It will take place in April 2025 and will have queer art vendors, queer/trans yoga, an exhibit with student, staff, and faculty art, and more. We are looking for students to serve on the planning working group. All students are welcome to apply. Interest form and more information can be found here: tinyurl.com/MammothPride Questions? Email hnicholas@amherst.edu

title: BREHA Lab: Theatre as a Tool for Political Engagement & Community Collaboration
event_description: Join the BREHA Collective for two impactful events featuring Jamaican feminist scholar and playwright Dr. Honor Ford-Smith! This includes a talk and facilitated discussion on 10/16 at 5:30pm in Cole Assembly Room in Converse Hall discussing theatre as a tool for political engagement and community collaboration as well as an embodied practice workshop, “Di City a Wi Yaad" on 10/17 at 4:30pm in Webster 220 exploring spatial memory and justice through monologue, sound, movement and zine-making.

title: BREHA Lab:  “Di City a Wi Yaad"
event_description: Join the BREHA Collective for two impactful events featuring Jamaican feminist scholar and playwright Dr. Honor Ford-Smith! This includes a talk and facilitated discussion on 10/16 at 5:30pm in Cole Assembly Room in Converse Hall discussing theatre as a tool for political engagement and community collaboration as well as an embodied practice workshop, “Di City a Wi Yaad" on 10/17 at 4:30pm in Webster 220 exploring spatial memory and justice through monologue, sound, movement and zine-making.

title: Exorcism = Liberation hub at Book & Plow
event_description:
In Exorcism = Liberation, artist Yanira Castro, AC ‘93,  focuses on future-building embedded in Puerto Rican culture and the U.S.’s colonial history in that region.

Book & Plow is one of many hubs for the Exorcism = Liberation project. We invite you to come up, scan the banner, and touch some soil while you listen. Check out the link for more information & to learn about upcoming local events!

title: Apply to be a Peer Educator with Residential Engagement & Wellbeing!
event_description: Interested in doing work on campus around wellbeing? Want to build skills around facilitation and programming? Looking to be a part of a collaborative team? Apply to work as a Peer Educator! Our work is possible in part due to the work of our paid student employees who lead programs, workshops, and tables on a variety of health and wellbeing topics. See application on Workday (JR-5522) to apply and also fill out the supplemental questions on the google form. Questions? Email rew@amherst.edu

title: Fall Break Wellness & Fitness Class Schedule
event_description:
Fall Break Schedule for Monday and Tuesday:

Monday ~ Yoga & Barre are both cancelled; Mat Pilates will happen on Zoom!

Tuesday ~ Walking for Fitness cancelled; Whole Body Strength & Zumba will be held at their usual times and locations!

title: Naloxone Training with REW and Tapestry Health
event_description: Join Residential Engagement & Wellbeing (REW) for a lunch-and-learn naloxone training with facilitators from Tapestry Health. Participants will learn how to recognize the signs of an opioid overdose and how they can respond using naloxone nasal spray. The cost of Valentine Dining Hall lunch will be covered by REW for attendees; pre-register for the session at tinyurl.com/rew-naloxone. Questions and/or accessibility needs? Email Taya Westfield (twestfield@amherst.edu).

title: Share Your Amherst Experiences as an Admission Office Blogger!
event_description:
Each year, the Admission Office selects a group of enthusiastic Amherst College students to blog about their Amherst experiences.  These blogs (displayed on our WordPress site) allow you to share your firsthand insights about Amherst with prospective students—and in turn, allow prospective students to envision themselves on campus.

This is a paid one-hour-per-week commitment. No in-office time required after initial training; the work may be done on your own schedule.

title: Amherst College Event Calendar
event_description: See what's happening today!
